Key Arguments: The legislation is seen as an invasion of the democratic right to freedom of expression and speech.
Concerns about government overreach and the potential for Australia to become a 'nanny state'.
Skepticism about the accuracy and impartiality of fact-checking processes.
Belief that individuals should be allowed to discern information for themselves without government interference.
Comparison to social credit systems and fears of punitive measures for free speech.
Notable Quotes: This Bill, if enacted, will be an obtrusive invasion and breech of our human democratic right to freedom of expression and speech.
This has got a CCP stamp of Social Credit Scores all over it and is a slippery slope which should never be set into action or law.
We do not need a government chosen entity monitoring and censoring information that is being shared.
